conclusion: Understanding the problem involves finding the temperature at state B for an ideal gas.
The p-V diagram shows state changes from A to B to C with axes for volume and pressure.
At state A, pressure is 3 × 10^5 Pa and volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
At state B, pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa and volume is 1 × 10^-3 m³.
At state C, pressure is 1 × 10^5 Pa and volume is 3 × 10^-3 m³.
From A to B, pressure decreases while volume stays the same; from B to C, volume increases at constant pressure.
Temperature at state A is given as 27°C.
Using the ideal gas law PV = nRT for calculations.
With constant volume, P ∝ T, so P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂.
Convert T₁ from Celsius to Kelvin: 27°C = 300 K.
Calculate T₂ using P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂: T₂ = (1 × 10^5 / 3 × 10^5) * 300 = 100 K.
Convert T₂ from Kelvin to Celsius: 100 K - 273.15 = -173.15°C.
Consideration of ideal gas law sufficiency without heat exchange.
Mention of 'a certain quality' of gas not affecting ideal gas law application.
A to B is an isochoric process, so temperature changes with pressure.
Verification using n = P₁V₁ / (R T₁) = P₂V₂ / (R T₂) confirms T₂ = 100 K.
